author: Brandon Schwartz
bottom_line: Areas of unstable surface wet snow are expected to form quickly this morning in response to rapid warming. Natural cornice fall is also a concern. The best bet for today is to time travel in avalanche terrain during the early morning hours and to consider avoiding avalanche terrain from late morning onwards.
hazard_discussion:
• A colder start to the day yesterday delayed most wet loose avalanche occurrences until the midday to afternoon hours. A much warmer start this morning and increased heating will allow for wet snow instability to occur much earlier today.
  • Recent new snow is expected to have assimilated with the older melt-freeze crust below it on E-SE-S-SW-W aspects in areas that received three inches or less of new snowfall on Friday. Areas that were wind loaded or received more snow will take longer for the recent new snow to transition to uniform melt-freeze in the upper snowpack.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Air temperature inversion conditions are giving most slopes a head start on melting this morning. Many upper elevation areas are already at 40 degrees at sunrise. Last night's snow surface refreeze was fully dependent on radiational cooling of the snowpack under clear skis. A weak to decent snow surface refreeze is expected to have occurred on open slopes. Areas under forest canopy may not have refrozen at all. 

It's April and the sun angles are now high enough to create wet snow on all aspects. Long open slopes with sustained slope angles will have the potential to create the largest wet loose avalanches. In areas where rollerballs or pinwheels are occurring or the upper snowpack is wet and unsupportable, consider moving to slopes less steep than about 35 degrees in slope angle to reduce the risk of becoming caught in a wet loose avalanche.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wet Loose
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wet Loose avalanches are the release of wet unconsolidated snow or slush. These avalanches typically occur within layers of wet snow near the surface of the snowpack, but they may quickly gouge into lower snowpack layers. Like Loose Dry Avalanches, they start at a point and entrain snow as they move downhill, forming a fan-shaped avalanche. Other names for loose-wet avalanches include point-release avalanches or sluffs. Loose Wet avalanches can trigger slab avalanches that break into deeper snow layers.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
There is an increased likelihood of a natural cornice fall cycle today and tomorrow. Some of the cornices out there near treeline and above treeline on N-NE-E aspects range in size from very large to massive. Falling blocks of very dense snow will have some destructive potential.

The exact moment that a cornice fall will occur is nearly impossible to predict and is often larger than expected. Nearly everyone involved in a cornice fall incident while on a ridgetop is caught by surprise when the cornice breaks off much further back from the edge than expected. Stay well back from cornice areas on ridgetops by staying close to exposed rocks or trees. Consider avoiding travel on slopes underneath cornices.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Cornice Fall
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Cornice Fall is the release of an overhanging mass of snow that forms as the wind moves snow over a sharp terrain feature, such as a ridge, and deposits snow on the downwind (leeward) side. Cornices range in size from small wind drifts of soft snow to large overhangs of hard snow that are 30 feet (10 meters) or taller. They can break off the terrain suddenly and pull back onto the ridge top and catch people by surprise even on the flat ground above the slope. Even small cornices can have enough mass to be destructive and deadly. Cornice Fall can entrain loose surface snow or trigger slab avalanches.
